Authors:
Thomas Lecocq, Denis Michez, Audrey Coppée, Simon
Dellicour, Irena Valterová, Jean-Yves Rasplus, Pierre Rasmont
Title:
Evolution of courtship signal traits in insular
bumblebees
Abstract:
The courtship signal allows pre-mating recognition. Its
evolution depends on the sexual selective pressure mainly leaded by the
interspecific interaction. In sympatry with Close Related Species (CRS),
the selection for specific signals to avoid mismatch make this pressure
stabilizing. This leads to a saltationnal evolution across phylogenetic
lineage. Conversely, in allopatry with CRS, as in many insular systems,
the lack of hydridization risk may promote a relaxation of the
stabilizing selection and change the courtship signal evolution. We
tested this hypothesis using genetic and chemical comparative approachs
on a courtship signal trait, the Sexual Marking Pheronones (SMP) of four
bumblebee species including Coriscan insular (allopatry with CRS) and
mainland (sympatry with CRS) population. Analyses showed 1) genetic and
SMP differentions of insulars and, 2) a lower genetic variability and a
higher SMP variability of insular. A correlation between the neutral
loci distance and the SMP distance was detected for the insulars.
Differentiations of Corsican bumblebees have lead to a rapid speciation
in about 15000 years. The incrase of the SMP variability and the
correlation genetic-SMP suggested a relaxation of the stabilizing
selection on the courtship signal leading to a gradual differentiation
in insular system with species free of their CRS.
